Record.Value: Learn how to create an airtight room that can pressurise and depressurise.

Welcome back, Cadet! Due to an unfortunate pressurization glitch, a catastrophic failure occurred and destroyed the Airlock.
Let's rebuild it!

In this lesson, we need to create an Airlock to replace the broken one. We will be utilizing vents, pipes, consoles and motherboards.
Lets start off with a basic Airlock. First, build the outer {THING:ItemIronFrames} for the Airlock. Frames are recommended as you can attach smaller items to them. Find the {THING:ItemIronFrames} in the yellow crate.
Now make the {THING:ItemIronFrames} airtight by finishing them with some Iron Sheets from the orange crate.
Use the {THING:ItemKitDoor} from the yellow crate to build two {THING:StructureCompositeDoor} in the highlighted spots.
Pick up the {THING:ItemLabeller} from the crate.

Go ahead and finish constructing each {THING:StructureCompositeDoor} with {THING:ItemPlasticSheets} and {THING:ItemGlassSheets}. You then need to rename the newly built doors using the {THING:ItemLabeller}, which can be found in the orange crate.

Next, set up a {THING:StructureGasSensor} and an {THING:StructureActiveVent}. A {THING:StructureGasSensor} is a key component in the Airlock, as it informs the console of the current atmosphere inside it, while the {THING:StructureActiveVent} pressurizes and depressurizes the Airlock.
Build the {THING:StructureGasSensor} in the highlighted location.
Build the {THING:StructureActiveVent} in the highlighted location.

{THING:ItemKitPipe} are used to carry gases from one point to another. We will need to connect the {THING:StructureActiveVent} to the {THING:StructurePassiveVent} using {THING:ItemKitPipe}.
Note: When building an Airlock you can store the gases in the pipe itself, if you don’t have access to a {THING:StructurePassiveVent}.
Set up a {THING:StructureConsole} by placing it on the wall in the highlighted spot.

To complete the {THING:StructureConsole} we need to add a circuit board to it. There are different types of circuit boards for different situations. You're building an Airlock, so you need to use the {THING:CircuitboardAirlockControl}. You will also need to use a data disk to allow the {THING:CircuitboardAirlockControl} to be programmed.
Place {THING:ItemGlassSheets} on the {THING:StructureConsole} to complete the console.

To programme the Airlock, turn on the {THING:StructureConsole}. Select the {THING:StructureActiveVent} and {THING:StructureGasSensor}. Devices highlight green with red text when selected.
Select the two Airlock doors. Selecting one door as 'Exterior' will cause the other to default to 'Internal'. Ensure the doors are correctly assigned.
Once a device is selected, that device will be locked under its control, and will not respond to interactions unless deselected.
When you have successfully completed the Airlock set up, the switch on the side of the {THING:StructureConsole} will light up green. You may now remove the Data Disk from the {THING:StructureConsole}. The Console will be locked, and will not respond to interactions unless you reinsert the Data Disk.

Now to test the newly built Airlock. Press the “Cycle to Interior” button to start pressurization. The Airlock pressure must reach at least 101 kPa for the cycle to complete. If the base within is not pressurized, the airlock cannot complete its cycle. If this happens press the “Cancel pressurize” button.
Remove the {THING:ItemDataDisk} and cycle to interior.

Now that you have a basic Airlock, lets make a few upgrades to convert it into an Advanced Airlock.
Basic Airlocks work well on planets with no atmosphere, but to prevent poisonous gases or extreme temperatures entering your base, you need an Advanced Airlock. These pump atmosphere out, before pressurising the Airlock with the desired atmosphere.
To create an advanced Airlock you will need to build another {THING:StructureActiveVent} inside it, and a passive vent outside, then connect them with pipes.
Place an {THING:StructureActiveVent} in the highlighted spot in the airlock.
Now that the structures are in place, we need to swap out the {THING:CircuitboardAirlockControl} for the {THING:CircuitboardAdvAirlockControl}.
Remove the {THING:ItemGlassSheets} from the {THING:StructureConsole} with the crowbar.

There are a few differences when programming the {THING:CircuitboardAdvAirlockControl}.
First, rename the new vent 'External Vent' and the old vent 'Internal Vent', to identify them on the console. Select each {THING:StructureActiveVent}, ensuring to assign them correctly.
The last thing you need to do is select the desired internal and external pressure, found near the top of the {THING:CircuitboardAdvAirlockControl} panel. Make sure the Airlock works by pressing the “Cycle to Interior” button.
